lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly use “’ve got” and “’s got” in statements (e.g., “We’ve got short legs.” / “She’s got short legs.”).
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write “We’ve got short legs.” / “She’s got long arms.” Students identify subject and verb. Then make their own sentence from SB images.
stretchStrategies: ❝Team Grammar Race❞ – Write mixed-up sentences on the board (e.g., “short legs got I’ve”). In small groups, students race to fix them by writing the correct form underneath. Use only a whiteboard and markers.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify CVC words (e.g., bat, cat, fox).
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say bat, cat, fox. Students repeat and circle the words with matching initial or final sounds in their SB or worksheet.
stretchStrategies: ❝Team Grammar Race❞ – Write mixed-up sentences on the board (e.g., “short legs got I’ve”). In small groups, students race to fix them by writing the correct form underneath. Use only a whiteboard and markers.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete sentence frames (e.g., “I’ve got short legs.” / “He’s got big feet.”) using “’ve got” or “’s got” correctly.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Show frame: “I’ve got ___.” or “They’ve got ___.” Students complete with correct structure and descriptive word.
stretchStrategies: ❝Team Grammar Race❞ – Write mixed-up sentences on the board (e.g., “short legs got I’ve”). In small groups, students race to fix them by writing the correct form underneath. Use only a whiteboard and markers.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
